qas.question: During the 1500 who was a valued part of the Ottoman   Empire?
What did the Ottoman Empire provide to its people?

answers.text: freedom of movement for citizens and goods

qas.question: What was the local language during this time in Egypt?
When did the Ottoman Empire disband?
What key feature made Algeria a vital part of the Ottoman empire?
What was the language of Europe?
What culture did Tuareg clans enforce?
What kind of rule did the kingdom of Algeria have?

context: In the 16th century the northern fringe of the Sahara, such as coastal regencies in present-day Algeria and Tunisia, as well as some parts of present-day Libya, together with the <b7_0>semi-autonomous<b7_0/> kingdom of Egypt, were occupied by the Ottoman Empire. From <b3_0>1517<b3_0/> <a0_0>Egypt<a0_0/> was a valued part of the Ottoman Empire, ownership of which provided the Ottomans with <b4_0>control over the Nile Valley<b4_0/>, the east Mediterranean and North Africa. The benefit of the Ottoman Empire was the <a1_0>freedom of movement for citizens and goods<a1_0/>. Trade exploited the Ottoman land routes to handle the spices, gold and silk from the East, manufactures from Europe, and the slave and gold traffic from Africa. <a2_0><b5_0>Arabic<b5_0/><a2_0/> continued as the local language and <b6_0>Islamic<b6_0/> culture was much reinforced. The Sahel and southern Sahara regions were home to several independent states or to roaming Tuareg clans.
